componenttextpreview: Dan, I think the macro environment, on the gas side, underpinning demand of the need for large pipe as you take away from these shale regions from the Marcellus to Utica. The need for midstream will come back, and you'll see some smaller pipe. They are mo
componenttext: Dan, I think the macro environment, on the gas side, underpinning demand of the need for large pipe as you take away from these shale regions from the Marcellus to Utica. The need for midstream will come back, and you'll see some smaller pipe. They are moving different product as well across into the Gulf Coast. So yes, I think it's coming back some. It's not prolific by any means but the large pipe should overcome any kind of shortfall you would see in that area. And the outlook is good. We continue to bid a lot of work and see a lot of work in that area, so we're optimistic.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Noelle Dilts with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question is from Noelle Dilts with Stifel.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to started on the transmission side of the business. Going back to last quarter, I note that if you strip out some of the charges and looked at the U.S. market, your margins were quite good. It looks like continued progress there this quarter. So
componenttext: I wanted to started on the transmission side of the business. Going back to last quarter, I note that if you strip out some of the charges and looked at the U.S. market, your margins were quite good. It looks like continued progress there this quarter. So could you speak to the trends you're seeing from profitability standpoint in the U.S. and Canada? And how you see that tracking through 2017?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The transmission business, it looks good. The larger projects is the timing. So we're always concerned with the timing of the larger projects of our larger transmission business on really both side of the business. But the electric side, we did start some
componenttext: The transmission business, it looks good. The larger projects is the timing. So we're always concerned with the timing of the larger projects of our larger transmission business on really both side of the business. But the electric side, we did start some projects, we're on 3 big projects now. So we're moving forward on some bigger ones. But the underpinning -- underlying base business as we continue to talk about, it's good. There's demand there. We continue to grow that business. We're excited about it as we stated, where headcounts higher, we continue to invest in our workforce. So we like -- we see the capital spends of our customers, we're talking to them daily so we're able to understand where they're going. And you can look at what they say on our earnings calls and we believe the capital spends will increase over the next few years, especially that we could see. So the underlying business will continue to grow and some of the larger projects will come in on top of that. And Canada, just a little bit on that. It's more dependent on your energy, on your oil and where oil pricing is. So it's really difficult for us to try to pin that down on where the larger projects are going. We have continued to get our cost structure in line with what the market is. We do have some nice projects in backlog that we believe will move forward in '17. So we're in pretty good shape for a foreseeable future in Canada.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Noelle, I'll just color on from a margin perspective. You've seen here in the third quarter that if you exclude the power plant, that we posted a number, it's effectively double-digit numbers in electric power segment. We talked about our ability to b
componenttext: And Noelle, I'll just color on from a margin perspective. You've seen here in the third quarter that if you exclude the power plant, that we posted a number, it's effectively double-digit numbers in electric power segment. We talked about our ability to beat that back there. That is partly because of the cost control efforts in Canada, but it's also because of the strong margins in the U.S. The U.S. market, as it stands here today for 2016, we are executing as a double-digit margin profile. The pressure for the year is partly coming from MLP, obviously, but as well as some of the pressure associated with the Canadian market. But that's where our cost control efforts have predominantly been. And as we look forward, we can see the opportunity to be working on a couple of those larger projects in '17 so a combination of the cost control and those larger projects we think bode well for Canadian margins. At least to lessen the dilution that's currently being created by Canada. But the U.S. market is still operating well and we think we're very much focused on returning the Canadian margins to a greater benefit.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In fact, that was really helpful. So my second question is just kind a broader question on the pipeline space. I think for anyone following the industry sort of continued to see headwinds about projects just getting pushed out 6, 9 months from '17 into '1
componenttext: In fact, that was really helpful. So my second question is just kind a broader question on the pipeline space. I think for anyone following the industry sort of continued to see headwinds about projects just getting pushed out 6, 9 months from '17 into '18 or '18 to '19. My question for you is have any of these delays changed how you're thinking about '17? Or is it sort of power for the course and maybe we're just looking at the more dependent cycle?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've talked about in the past being broader and longer versus any peaks. And that's still holds true. We watch all of these larger projects in our gas business and to make sure we give good guidance on where we think we're going to go. We've
componenttext: Yes, I think we've talked about in the past being broader and longer versus any peaks. And that's still holds true. We watch all of these larger projects in our gas business and to make sure we give good guidance on where we think we're going to go. We've got it. We see some pushes, we built that and into our system when we look at things. Some of it you can't tell when it's coming and it just happens. But for the most part, I think we have that under control and we understand when these projects are going to go. It won't allow us to give guidance on a 3-month interval but we should be able to get some qualitative comments that says the macro demand on large diameter pipe is there. There'll be some permitting delays that will build into any kind of guidance we give along with seasonality. But I do think the next few years on large diameter pipe, especially, look really good for us.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jamie Cook with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jamie Cook with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of questions. Derrick, how dilutive was Canada to earnings this year? And then just to follow up on that, you talked about within oil and gas the 1 project being deferred is getting pushed into 2017, can you quantify that? So that's my n
componenttext: I guess, a couple of questions. Derrick, how dilutive was Canada to earnings this year? And then just to follow up on that, you talked about within oil and gas the 1 project being deferred is getting pushed into 2017, can you quantify that? So that's my nitpicky question. And my real question is, Derrick or Duke, whoever wants to answer this, are there -- I understand you don't want to give specific margin guidance for 2017 but are there any headwind that we can make our own assumptions on market. Are there any headwinds that you know of today that would depress margins in '17 because, I mean, I'm just thinking we have Alaska, that's gone. We have Canada, which should be less of a headwind you've restructured. I just don't understand why margins shouldn't be materially higher when we're thinking about '17 versus '16, you have endowment, you're investing in technology, there just seems to be a whole bunch of negative that go away in '16 that would imply a much higher EPS number for '17.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, on the first part of it, dilutive Canada, I don't that if I could comment to, to exactly what operating income type levels of Canada but I can tell you that from an overall Canada, for at least the electric power, you're talking about low single-di
componenttext: Jamie, on the first part of it, dilutive Canada, I don't that if I could comment to, to exactly what operating income type levels of Canada but I can tell you that from an overall Canada, for at least the electric power, you're talking about low single-digit margins in comparison. The international revenues right now run about 15% of our consolidated revenues. And that include some Latin American and some Australian work with Canada that gives you in the is probably running 10% to 15% range. So you can kind of do some backwards math looking at the relative dilution. Oil and gas pushed to '17, quantification, I would tell you that the largest portion of our revenue adjustment for the year is associated with those individual oil and gas projects. And then for margin guidance for '17, I can color first and just simply say that I think your assessments, not unfair, mainly even if we just look at the elimination of MLP year-over-year, we don't know that we're going to see any sizable moves from a cost structure perspective, from a G&A perspectives or the rest is going to come down largely to execution and the timing of the projects. But I'll let Duke comment on that.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, qualitatively, I would say, yes, everything you said was accurate. We do see good markets in '17. I think that comes down to execution which I'm confident we can execute. So I like the market, I like where we're going. I think the company's positio
componenttext: Jamie, qualitatively, I would say, yes, everything you said was accurate. We do see good markets in '17. I think that comes down to execution which I'm confident we can execute. So I like the market, I like where we're going. I think the company's positioned well with feet on the ground, we can build winter construction very, very well. So I'm confident in the company and I'm confident in the markets in 2017. The things that give me pause would only be Canadian economy and oil pricing there, concerns me a bit. And then for permitting. So we'll be watching some of that as we move forward but that's only on the large projects. And I'll continue to say our base business continues to go the right direction and we see that going in the right direction in 2017.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tahira Afzal with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tahira Afzal with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Duke, if you look at your 12-month backlog, it's showing sort of a 5% type of increase. But if you look at the new work you could potentially book, does that seem to imply that, directionally, your revenue growth could be 5%-plus even in the high single d
componenttext: Duke, if you look at your 12-month backlog, it's showing sort of a 5% type of increase. But if you look at the new work you could potentially book, does that seem to imply that, directionally, your revenue growth could be 5%-plus even in the high single digits potentially?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't want to get into exactly where, from a percentage, what I do know is that the base business is growing both segments. What gives us pause on saying there's growth on top is the start of the larger projects. And so it gives -- we do, we are bu
componenttext: Yes, I don't want to get into exactly where, from a percentage, what I do know is that the base business is growing both segments. What gives us pause on saying there's growth on top is the start of the larger projects. And so it gives -- we do, we are building our backlog. We continue to build our backlog. It's just the starts. And when we put these larger projects in backlog. So in saying that, the larger projects complicates that whole scenario and we'll continue to be conservative about how we approach that.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, okay. Okay, I get that. And then, Duke, as a really follow-up to that, I'll be -- when we look at some of the pipeline project and how they're playing out or sizing up, it does seem that your normal seasonality will be somewhat different as we
componenttext: All right, okay. Okay, I get that. And then, Duke, as a really follow-up to that, I'll be -- when we look at some of the pipeline project and how they're playing out or sizing up, it does seem that your normal seasonality will be somewhat different as we go into 2017. So with stable [indiscernible] project sort of really trickling into the first half, would you say that the first half is comparatively going to be stronger as we see it right now?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It is. It should. There's no reason why the first half would be stronger than the first half of this year based on the work we have ongoing. The concern is the second half and what that looks like. So we'll be trying to provide better guidance here i
componenttext: Yes. It is. It should. There's no reason why the first half would be stronger than the first half of this year based on the work we have ongoing. The concern is the second half and what that looks like. So we'll be trying to provide better guidance here in February on that.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrew Kaplowitz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Kaplowitz with Citigroup.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is, Allan for Andy this morning. Duke, could you maybe provide an update on pricing and major businesses? Have you seen any lessening in price competition, I'm sorry, competition within the electric transmission? Some of the large project activities
componenttext: This is, Allan for Andy this morning. Duke, could you maybe provide an update on pricing and major businesses? Have you seen any lessening in price competition, I'm sorry, competition within the electric transmission? Some of the large project activities started to kind of rebound here. And has there been any change in behavior on customer on mainline pipe side as capacity seems like it's gotten a little bit tighter here especially in the second half of the year?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the first part of your question, from our standpoint, pretty disciplined about how we bid all the time. Our customers -- we continue to put the same profile. We look at risk, is how we price. And so our risk profile has not changed. As we get busier, o
componenttext:
On the first part of your question, from our standpoint, pretty disciplined about how we bid all the time. Our customers -- we continue to put the same profile. We look at risk, is how we price. And so our risk profile has not changed. As we get busier, our utilization rates and things of that nature go up and allows our margins to enhance. So as we get busier, as the projects -- the larger projects are there, we get better utilization. As we talked about in the past, we had people that were on the sidelines, they are now going to work on some of these larger projects or weren't as efficient on the smaller ones and so you'll start to see -- that's why you're starting to see some of the margin enhancement as well as our base business continues to grow. So that will allow some utilization there. And our Canadian operations, we have rightsized some of that and we'll move forward there. It's really about Canada for us on the margins to make sure that we get that in line. And some of the projects there, I would say, are out of our pricing discipline and will allow the others to win those and we'll continue to say disciplined on how we bid work.
And on the gas side, we continue to be the same way, it's no different.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up on Canada, I think in your prepared remarks, you said you're starting to see some signs of early recovery. Can you just give us a little more color on what you are seeing that gives you a little more optimism there?
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up on Canada, I think in your prepared remarks, you said you're starting to see some signs of early recovery. Can you just give us a little more color on what you are seeing that gives you a little more optimism there?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think our backlog, we have a large project in our backlog, as everyone is aware of and that will go into construction as we stand today in 2017. So it allows us to get better utilized there, that is some flexibility on what we do in Canada. I wo
componenttext: I mean, I think our backlog, we have a large project in our backlog, as everyone is aware of and that will go into construction as we stand today in 2017. So it allows us to get better utilized there, that is some flexibility on what we do in Canada. I would say, the overall market just continues on oil pricing in many ways and so it a little fluctuates, so does Canada. So we watch that as we move forward and we will continue to adjust with the markets that we see.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Derrick, maybe a question for you on cash flow. It seems like a lot of the weakness this quarter was timing-related and working capital. And obviously, this delayed receivable. But how soon do you think we can resee a return to more normalized cash co
componenttext: And Derrick, maybe a question for you on cash flow. It seems like a lot of the weakness this quarter was timing-related and working capital. And obviously, this delayed receivable. But how soon do you think we can resee a return to more normalized cash conversion levels for you guys?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the things that -- the primary thing I don't have -- give guidance on historically has been cash flow because of the very much of those timing things. I'll tell you that here in the fourth quarter, even to the extent that I get better collections o
componenttext: One of the things that -- the primary thing I don't have -- give guidance on historically has been cash flow because of the very much of those timing things. I'll tell you that here in the fourth quarter, even to the extent that I get better collections on historical kind of unbilled balances, I think I'm going to have a level of production on that project such I'm going to be probably flat this quarter versus year-end. So right now, I think I'm going to go ahead and say it wouldn't surprise me if my ending that balance for the year is fairly comparable to my current debt balance. And I think you'll see some of that may be a little more in the first part of next year.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chad Dillard with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chad Dillard with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in transmission, given that you're entering the plus 10% margin territory and you're in the early stages of ramping up large transmission, I'm just trying to think through the upsized scenario for margins over the next year or so. I'm in the back to 20
componenttext: So in transmission, given that you're entering the plus 10% margin territory and you're in the early stages of ramping up large transmission, I'm just trying to think through the upsized scenario for margins over the next year or so. I'm in the back to 2012 time frame, I see you about 12% margins. How much of an analog would that timeframe to where we are now? And has anything in your business or end market changed which would either limited to around 12% or allow you to surpass that previously?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again the market, we'll be in the 10% to 12% range when things are good as we've talked about in the past, to double-digit range. So what I would say is we're taking incremental steps. It's not something that -- it's something that will be incrementa
componenttext: Yes, again the market, we'll be in the 10% to 12% range when things are good as we've talked about in the past, to double-digit range. So what I would say is we're taking incremental steps. It's not something that -- it's something that will be incremental to us sequentially as we move along into next year. The market is not -- we're seeing work, we're winning work, we're bidding work, we're also not winning work. So it's hard to say exactly where the margins will go. We'll continue to try to get into our historical range.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relative to 2012, one of the things to point out is if you may recall, that is our largest storm work year really in Quanta history. I mean, we did over $250 million for the storm work. So that very much contributed to the margins being over 12%. And at t
componenttext: Relative to 2012, one of the things to point out is if you may recall, that is our largest storm work year really in Quanta history. I mean, we did over $250 million for the storm work. So that very much contributed to the margins being over 12%. And at the same time, in that timeframe, you are working on a significant number of larger projects. So although we do have the opportunity to have larger projects contributing as we go forward, I don't think we're still yet at the level of that. So there are a couple of dynamics that kept us very much in the upper side of that range and that is as we look forward, we probably that'll be a little aggressive to be thinking that we'd be that high in the your terms.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just pivoting over to the pipeline side, so can you speak to what you're seeing on distribution? What are your customers telling you about planning for 2017 and how should we think about that?
componenttext: Just pivoting over to the pipeline side, so can you speak to what you're seeing on distribution? What are your customers telling you about planning for 2017 and how should we think about that?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The distribution business is a good business. It's a steady business. We see the replacement with and some of the regulation that you see. That's a long-term replacement program across the country. It's broad-based. I think you'll continue to see that ove
componenttext: The distribution business is a good business. It's a steady business. We see the replacement with and some of the regulation that you see. That's a long-term replacement program across the country. It's broad-based. I think you'll continue to see that over the next 10, 15 years, continue to see us growing that business.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andy Wittmann with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andy Wittmann with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to ask on the pipeline segment and just trying to get some context around the opportunities that are out there by asking you, if you can just give us a sense of the dollar amount of projects that you believe you won but has been unable to
componenttext: I guess I wanted to ask on the pipeline segment and just trying to get some context around the opportunities that are out there by asking you, if you can just give us a sense of the dollar amount of projects that you believe you won but has been unable to announce. These projects that are held up by permitting or other factors. And what's the duration of those that you can best estimate the duration of time that, that's going to take to take those release?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think from our standpoint, the larger projects, there's many of them out there. It's about which 1 go and to give any sort of guidance on that it's very difficult. What I would say is we have -- we can see out fairly, fairly long here and the macro
componenttext: Yes, I think from our standpoint, the larger projects, there's many of them out there. It's about which 1 go and to give any sort of guidance on that it's very difficult. What I would say is we have -- we can see out fairly, fairly long here and the macro piece of it is there. The underpinning demand is there from a power side. So it's a robust environment. So it's a robust bidding environment. It's the timing, the permitting and things like that. That's not our expertise and we can't give guidance on that. What we can say is we do see the company in a good position to win work and execute work in the next few years.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. May be as kind of in attendance to that last question, can you give us some thoughts around -- have you been seeing more mainline projects coming your way over the last 18 months or so? Or is the body of work that you're looking at potentially doing
componenttext: Okay. May be as kind of in attendance to that last question, can you give us some thoughts around -- have you been seeing more mainline projects coming your way over the last 18 months or so? Or is the body of work that you're looking at potentially doing, is it the same stuff that's been contemplated for many years? In other words, has the oil price declines, has that affected the amount of new work that coming your way in terms of opportunity side?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at the pipeline business, it's much cheaper to move product through pipe than it is rail. And if you look at what was rail in the past, and becomes an economical. So you're starting to see more people took pipelines on the drawing boar
componenttext: I think if you look at the pipeline business, it's much cheaper to move product through pipe than it is rail. And if you look at what was rail in the past, and becomes an economical. So you're starting to see more people took pipelines on the drawing board for where rail lines may have been in the past. So I think the overall economics of the large pipelines in moving product is there. It continues to be a robust bidding environment and a multiyear bidding environment. So we are having concept contacts with our customers negotiating, looking at work with them. And we like the environment.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Duncan with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Duncan with Stephens.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I've got just on back on the oil and gas segment for a little bit. So trying to think through the project timing as we look out into next year, certainly not looking for guidance for the year but really kind of the flow of what you see in b
componenttext: First question I've got just on back on the oil and gas segment for a little bit. So trying to think through the project timing as we look out into next year, certainly not looking for guidance for the year but really kind of the flow of what you see in backlog. So you had some stuff that's pushed in the first half, some are going to pretty big first half, Atlantic Coast is not supposed to start until later in the year. So it sounds like there's the potential for a little bit of a sort of abnormal flow to the year with kind of air pocket in the third quarter which would normally be the high watermark for the year. Should we be thinking that, that's kind of the flow of the year, unless you pick up a project kind of in between Sable Trail and other the stuff you're working on one when a Atlantic Coast goes?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, again there's a multitude of projects that we're looking at. We talked about Atlantic Coast, it's one of them. We don't necessarily -- we have our own timing in a way that we think about where I would say the second half is -- we're not started on it
componenttext: Yes, again there's a multitude of projects that we're looking at. We talked about Atlantic Coast, it's one of them. We don't necessarily -- we have our own timing in a way that we think about where I would say the second half is -- we're not started on it yet so it will take us until February to kind of figure that out when we give guidance. And it's too early to say what the third quarter would look like there. Again, I'd see the same thing you see when you're looking at it from your viewpoint. So we'll try to be transparent when we give guidance there in February. It's just early today.

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That helps. Then I wanted to come back to sort of thinking about margin. So you've laid out targets of 10% to 11% for electrical and 9% to 12% for oil and gas. Electrical, you're now hitting the low end of that with Canada should sort of as a drag and For
componenttext: That helps. Then I wanted to come back to sort of thinking about margin. So you've laid out targets of 10% to 11% for electrical and 9% to 12% for oil and gas. Electrical, you're now hitting the low end of that with Canada should sort of as a drag and Forth MapQuest is going to startup presumably the relatively early next year. Is there any reason kind of going back to what Jamie is asking earlier, is there any reason why you can't get into the 10% to 11% range in electrical next year? And then with oil and gas, the large diameter stuff is the best margin work you do. I understand that there's probably drags from really low profit levels on more of the gathering work you're doing, but sort of if you can help us think through the moving pieces of all these segments and especially in electrical, having a hard time understanding how you don't get into the 10% to 11% range?

headline: Quanta Services, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as it relates to this quarter, and again if you exclude power plant, you saw our margins that were in the 10% range. But it's important to remember that, that's also our highest margin quarter, typically from a seasonality perspective. And so when
componenttext: Yes, so as it relates to this quarter, and again if you exclude power plant, you saw our margins that were in the 10% range. But it's important to remember that, that's also our highest margin quarter, typically from a seasonality perspective. And so when you kind of model out how we think the fourth quarter is going to play, I think you're going to model out that you're going to see margins dropping below 10% in the electric power segment because of that seasonality. We think the seasonality will definitely be impacting the quarters of 2017. For the last few years, you've seen a lot less of that seasonal dynamic because of the contributions of Canada. But as we stand here today, you see lesser contributions of Canada both from volume perspective as well as because of the fact that the overall performance of Canada is contributing at a lower margin level. So although it's too soon to comment as exactly how guidance will play out, I think those are important factors to think about when you think about our ability to maintain double-digit margins in every quarter of '17. I think seasonal impacts will exist and so that will be putting some level of pressure in our ability be it at double digits throughout the year. Relative to oil and gas, it's a big factor as to when the individual projects starts and stops i individual quarters. Thinking about the second quarter commentary that we provided on the fourth quarter of this year, we talked about potential for the ability for margins to see an uptick. As we stand here today, we're not seeing that because of the timing of those projects. Those projects pushing out into the fourth quarter. So any of those individuals starts to top the project were much influenced the mix of the work in the quarters and therefore, for the year. And that's the biggest portion of what drives the level of margins being up in the double-digit range for oil and gas at this stage. Higher levels at given times in given quarters for those large-diameter pipe definitely give us ability to be there. But as Duke commentary talked about, to center yet comment how the back half of the real play out to be able to really feel out the ability to be a double-digit margins right now.

On a broad spectrum both in Canada, Australia and the U.S. and always have on the front end of these projects. The environment is good, as I've said. There are underpinning demands there. There's a need for natural gas all across the Lower 48, Canada, just from the power plant side is the coal-to-gas switching happens. You start to see the LDC use more natural gas. We're bullish on the pipe business for the foreseeable feature here.
